_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Bama Companies, Inc. - Bama Pie facility abides by the emergency response procedures and policies detailed in the Bama Safety Plan manual.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1.)    To save lives.

2.)    To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.)    To protect the environment.

4.)    To minimize property damage.



Bama Pie maintains an emergency response team whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes. 





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Bama Pie facility prepares frozen bakery products for distribution.  Prior to December 2003, the facility operated a small ammonia refrigeration system that was not applicable to the EPA Risk Management Program regulation.  The facility underwent a major expansion, and operations on the newly expanded system began in December 2003.  As a result of the expansion, the facility is required to comply with Program Level 3 of the EPA RMP.



Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the refrigeration process.  The refrigeration process, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for process equipment and cold storage rooms.  Typical operating conditions range from vacuum (approximately 15.5" Hg) on the low pressure side of the system to 150-160 psig on the high side.



The to

tal ammonia inventory is 37,000 pounds.  





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:



1)  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and

2)  EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).



The facility also follows recognized and good engineering practices that comply with state and local codes and IIAR standards.



It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors throughout the facility which will alert plant personnel in the event of an ammonia detection.  





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



An investigation into the facility's accident history revealed that Bama Pie has not had any RMP reportable accidents in the last five years (June 2008 - June 2013).  Such "accidents" would involve serious accidents with either onsite deaths, injuries, or significant damage; or known, off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage.  In addition, there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds.  

        



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Bama Pie has an Emergency Response Program in place.  The facility has an Emergency Response Team that is trained to 24-hour Hazmat Technician Level initially and receives an 8-hour refresher on an annual basis.  Incident Commanders also receive 8-hour initial training and 8-hour annual refresher training.  Emergency Response Team m

embers that are trained in hazardous materials management and decontamination are fit tested and are trained in respiratory protection annually.   





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Bama Pie has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe work environment.  A Compliance Audit was completed in November 14-17, 2011. The initial Process Hazard Analysis was completed in November 21, 2003 and the PHA was revalidated on December 1, 2008 and November 11, 2013. Recommendations were generated during the 2003 PHA session, 2008 and 2013 revalidation studies, and the 2011 Compliance Audit to improve safety at the facility.
